title: Lorenzo Balducci
text:
Lorenzo Balducci (born 4 September 1982) is an Italian actor. He appeared in more than thirty films since 2001.
Life and career.
Balducci was born in Rome, Italy. He began taking acting classes when he was 14 and in November 2001 he made his stage debut as Romeo in a modern revival of <a href="William%20Shakespeare">William Shakespeare</a>'s "<a href="Romeo%20and%20Juliet">Romeo and Juliet</a>", also starring Italian actress Myriam Catania. He is openly gay.
After roles in a few TV commercials, he got a small part in <a href="Pupi%20Avati">Pupi Avati</a>'s "<a href="The%20Knights%20of%20the%20Quest">The Knights of the Quest</a>", that marked his film debut. Bigger roles quickly followed in films and television projects such as "", the acclaimed "<a href="Incantato">Incantato</a>" and the Italian box office hit "<a href="Three%20Steps%20Over%20Heaven">Three Steps Over Heaven</a>". His first lead role was in Luciano Melchionna's "Gas", an indie drama that was selected at the inaugural "<a href="Rome%20Film%20Festival">Rome Film Festival</a>" and for which he won the Best Actor Award at the "Chieti Film Festival".
He has appeared in more than thirty European <a href="films">films</a> and <a href="television%20series">television series</a> since then, including "Le héros de la famille", "The Stone Council" (both opposite <a href="Catherine%20Deneuve">Catherine Deneuve</a>), <a href="Andr%C3%A9%20T%C3%A9chin%C3%A9">André Téchiné</a>'s "<a href="The%20Witnesses">The Witnesses</a>", <a href="Krzysztof%20Zanussi">Krzysztof Zanussi</a>'s "<a href="Black%20Sun%20%282007%20film%29">Black Sun</a>", <a href="Carlos%20Saura">Carlos Saura</a>'s "<a href="I%2C%20Don%20Giovanni">I, Don Giovanni</a>" and the highly acclaimed Italian TV series "Le cose che restano". In 2009 he received the "<a href="Susan%20Batson">Susan Batson</a> Award" for his performance in "Due vite per caso" at the <a href="San%20Francisco">San Francisco</a>'s "NICE Film Festival".
Internationally, he starred in the Mexican romantic comedy "31 Días" (opposite <a href="Karla%20Souza">Karla Souza</a>), the controversial Spanish film "Estrella fugaz", the American TV movie "<a href="Barabbas%20%282012%20film%29">Barabbas</a>" (starring <a href="Billy%20Zane">Billy Zane</a>) and the Italian TV series "Mai per amore". He also appeared in the American independent comedy "<a href="In%20search%20of%20Fellini">In search of Fellini</a>" (opposite <a href="Maria%20Bello">Maria Bello</a>), the acclaimed short film "<a href="Snowflake%20%282014%20film%29">Snowflake</a>" (as <a href="Tracy%20Middendorf">Tracy Middendorf</a>'s love interest and for which he also served as an executive producer) and guest starred in the TV drama "".
In 2015 he was a member of the jury at the 30th <a href="Torino">Torino</a> Gay & Lesbian Film Festival.
On stage, Balducci has starred in several productions of "Dignità Autonome di Prostituzione" in both Italy and Spain and, in 2017, he was part of the ensemble cast of Luciano Melchionna's "Spoglia-Toy".
In 2018 he starred as John in "7 Miracles", one of the first feature-length cinematic VR experiences which premiered at the 26th <a href="Raindance%20Film%20Festival">Raindance Film Festival</a>, winning the “VR Film of the Festival” grand jury award.
In 2019 he reprised his role in Luciano Melchionna's acclaimed play "Spoglia-Toy" and played Giulio Mieli in "Gli anni amari", a <a href="biographical%20film">biopic</a> based on the life of <a href="Mario%20Mieli">Mario Mieli</a>, a leading figure in the Italian gay movement of the 1970s.
